fundamental_1.title:
Given:  
  
`console.log(myNum);`  
  
`var myNum;`  
  
`myNum = 5`   
  
 what value is logged?

labels.title: A reference error is thrown because variable is used before it's been declared.
`undefined` because in js declarations are hoisted.
None of the above.
A reference error is thrown because the variable is used without being declared. JS hoists declarations only.
`undefined` because in js initializations and declarations are hoisted.
None of the above.

fundamental_3.title:
Given:  
  
`console.log(myNum);`  
  
`if(1) {`  
 `let myNum = 5`  
  
 `}`  
  
  what value is logged?

labels.title: `Uncaught ReferenceError` because let is block scoped and so not hoisted outside the conditional.
`undefined` because in js initializations and declarations are hoisted.

fundamental_4.title: Which of the following are exclusively primitive *data types*?

labels.title: `number`, `bigint`, `boolean`, `undefined`, `null`
`string`, `number`, `bigint`, `boolean`, `undefined`, `symbol`
`Object`, `Array`, `Map`, `Set`, `Function`, `Date`
`Object`, `Array`, `Map`, `Set`, `boolean`, `undefined`

fundamental_5.title: What is the difference between `string` and `String`, `boolean` and `Boolean`, `symbol` and `Symbol` etc. ?

labels.title: The lowercase version is a primitive data type with no methods while the uppercase version is a wrapper object with methods.
There is no difference. Both can be used interchangeably.
The lowercase version is the value assigned by the uppercase version.
None of the above.

fundamental_6.title:
Given `let a = true;` and `let b = new Boolean(true);`  
  
What will `typeof a` and `typeof b` return?

labels.title: Both will return the string `boolean` since both pass in a boolean argument.
Both will return the string `object`
`boolean` and `object` respectively because the first is a primative value and the second is an instance of the Boolean constructor.
`object` and `boolean` respectively because `new Boolean()` always returns a primitive value.

symbol_1.title: What is the benefit of using the Symbol type?

labels.title: Holds key-value pairs and remembers the original insertion order of the keys.
Stores unique values of any type, whether primitive values or object references.
Creates a new unique value when called. They can used in place of strings or numbers meant to be unique in a system.
Represents the eventual completion (or failure) of an asynchronous operation and its resulting value.

symbol_2.title: What is the correct syntax to create a new `Symbol`?

labels.title: `const s = new Symbol()` initialize an instance with the `new` keyword.
`const s = Symbol('Sym1')` the `new` keyword is purposely not supported for JS Symbols.
`const s = Symbol.add('Sym1')` which adds a new Symbol to the global registry.
`const s = Symbol.create('Sym1')` which creates a new Symbol

symbol_3.title:
Given: `const s = Symbol('hello')`
  
 How would you access the Symbols descriptive string 'hello'?

labels.title: `Symbol.get('description')`
`s.description`
`s.description()`

promise_1.title: Which of the below is an example of a working Promise?

labels.title: `let p = new Promise((resolve, reject) => resolve(10) )`
`let p = new Promise(resolve(10))`
`let p = new Promise(() => return 10 )`

promise_2.title:
Given: `let p = new Promise((resolve, reject) => resolve(10) )`
  
 How would you set up chaining to return `30`?

labels.title: `p(result => result * 3);`
`p.then(result => result * 3);`
`p.resolve(result => result * 3)`

promise_3.title:
Given: `let p1 = new Promise(resolve => resolve(10));`
  
 `let p2 = new Promise(resolve => resolve(20));`
  
 Use `Promise.all` to show the results.

labels.title: `Promise.all(p1, p2).then(results => console.log(results))`
`Promise.all(p1, p2){results => console.log(results)}`
`Promise.all([p1, p2]).then(results => console.log(results))`

promise_4.title:
Given: `let p1 = new Promise(resolve => resolve(10));`
  
 `let p2 = new Promise((resolve, reject) => reject('Error!'));`
  
 What will `Promise.all([p1, p2]).then(result => console.log(result)).catch(err=>console.log(err))` return?

labels.title: `10` and then `Error!` because the first promise resolves and then the second promise rejects.
`Error!` because the `all()` return promise is rejected if any of it's input promises are rejected.
`10` because the first promise returns first.
